entry.title: Re: Search and Maintain Customer Extension Fields from Focused Build Fiori Application
entry.content:
Hello all!

I want to add a bit of knowledge, may be here is the right place.

If you want to transport your work from a SolMan Development System to a Production System, strangely, you have to repeat in the Production System the customizing for the table AXT_SYSTAB using transaction AXTSYS.

Usually this transaction is needed only in the development system, because it steers the way your AET extensions are recorded in a package and subsequently into a transport; the prefix is intended to avoid possible overwrites when AET extensions from more than one development system are transported  to the common productive system: you maintain for every development system a dedicated unique prefix and in the productive system the AET extensions will coexist.

This is also the reason why the maintenance of this table is local, as you can only have one prefix in one system.

And everything in FB works after your transport from FB Dev to FB Prod, you can use your FB Custom Fields in the Mass Change App and you can use them in the Analytics, except in the Document Fiori App itself :-]]]

The reason is that the Gateway service /SALM/CRM_SERVICE, when it reads the Custom Fields Entity Set, for some reason behaves differently than the other apps, because it wants to use the AXT_SYSTAB to determine the namespace of the AXT extension (usually "Z"), but ignoring the prefix, when constructing dynamically the Custom Fields names, thus breaking the CRM extension architecture.

So, SAP note https://me.sap.com/notes/3317607/E "Error when generating the Field Control properties for the Extension Fields - Focused Build" is incomplete (or a second note would be needed), because it addresses the execution of AXTSYS only in the development system, but oddly this local maintenance has to be repeated also on all subsequent SolMan systems. If you don't do this, you will see in the Fiori App the fragment titel "Custom Fields" appearing, but the fields are missing.

To create a data provider profile, you must have the following privilege assigned to your role: 

1. Spaces (Update) Privilege: This privilege is essential for both creating a new data provider profile and editing an existing one. 

To verify that you have this privilege, follow these steps:

2. Click on the Security section.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany Stock Transfer NET VALUE (1P9_MX) SAP S/...
entry.content:
Good day @AngelT 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

Intercompany Allocation, Manage Sales Price Workflows

Based on the details I can read on your screenshot, your condition record for P101 seems correctly maintained but the Intercompany Price condition is not being picked up in the billing document. That hints at either a missing or incorrect pricing procedure assignment in your intercompany setup.

Your invoice shows 0 net value because the condition type P101 is either not included in the pricing procedure or your billing document was created before you maintained the price condition. I suggest you check your pricing procedure, ensure P101 is active and then recreate the invoice to then apply pricing.

This Blog New Resource-Related Intercompany Billing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition also provides more insight.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Calculate the Critical Project Path with SAP Project and Resource Management
entry.content:
SAP Project and Resource Management (SAP PRM) enables to do bottom-up project scheduling, offering the flexibility to choose between forward and backward scheduling methods. Additionally, the tool visually highlights critical components in the Gantt Chart. This article provides insights into how the scheduling algorithm operates, the process of identifying critical elements, and the various types of scheduling conflicts that may arise.

Scheduling Method:
While editing the project plan, you have the option to choose your preferred scheduling method. To do so, click the 'Settings' button located in the top right corner. Currently Bottom-Up scheduling available and you can choose between Backward or Forward Scheduling.

Forward Scheduling:
When you select ‘Forward Scheduling’ in the ‘Settings’, the system uses the project start date to align the logical first project plan element (this can be Milestones or Work Packages) that does not have child-elements. Following this, other elements are organized according to their Parent-Child Hierarchy, Finish-to-Start Relationships, or Date Constraints. Then the dates are aggregated into a holistic project timeline. If any sequence conflicts arise, the system provides warnings for the impacted project plan elements (See the following section on ‘Conflicts’).

Backward Scheduling:
Backward scheduling similarly arranges project plan elements, but begins with the project end date, positioning the logical last element that has not child-elements underneath.

Critical Project Element Calculation:
When you click ‘Schedule’, the algorithm calculates both forward and backward scheduling, assigning Early Start and Early Finish Dates for forward scheduling, and Late Start and Late Finish Dates for backward scheduling. The Scheduled Dates are then copied to Planned Dates, which project managers can adjust as needed.

Project plan elements are highlighted as critical—like Critical Milestone or Critical Work Package—and colored red if their Float is zero. This may be due to their position on the critical path or a Must Start/Finish On constraint.

Conflicts:
As previously noted, various factors can lead to conflicts arising. For instance, two elements of a work project plan might not align correctly due to their relationship being out of sequence (refer to image 1), or child dates might not be properly aggregated (refer to image 2). The project plan elements that are impacted are highlighted, and warning messages will assist you in comprehending the conflict more thoroughly.


Image 1


Image 2

Milestone Calculation:
Since milestones lack a duration (they have only a Finish Date), when a Work Package consists solely of milestones as children, the duration of this Parent Work Package remains unaffected by its milestone children. However, this changes if additional work packages are defined as children.

Milestone Display:
Milestones are positioned based on their Finish Date, which is always displayed on the right end of the respective Date Bar.


Additional Information
For general insights into project scheduling with SAP PRM, refer to this blog post or explore specific details on Date Constraints and Bi-Directional Integration. For more comprehensive product details, please visit the product website.

entry.title: Wrong planning level assigned in MIRO
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts ,

 

I'd like some assistance or explanation for a system behavior .

While posting an invoice through MIRO , and while using a vendor that has the planning group field filled ( LFB1-FDGRV), the system takes the planning level from the reconciliation account of said vendor instead of the planning level assigned to the planning group .

If we empty the planning level from the reconciliation account, then the system takes the correct planning level from the group.

In fb60/FB50, this behavior is not present , and the correct planning level is taken from the planning group.

 

This is a problem because the planning level assigned to the group can be assigned to vendor line items , but the one in reconciliation account gives us the error RQ107, because it can only be assigned to GL line items.

 

Am i missing something in SPRO ? or is there a note i can implement .

Thank you for your help.

entry.title: Change of Work Package End Date gives error "Cannot update or delete. Actuals have been posted."
entry.content:
In Plan Customer Projects I try to change the Work Package End Date but get error message "Cannot update or delete. Actuals have been posted." even though there are no postings after the date I am entering.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Change of Work Package End Date gives error "Cannot u...
entry.content:
The system checks the Posting Date of actuals on the Work Package between the Start and End date. If an actual cost exists outside either the Start or End date then message "Cannot update or delete. Actuals have been posted." will be given. So, even though the user is only changing the End date, the system also checks the Start date.

Check in app Display Line Items in General Ledger for the range of Posting Dates for the Work Package and set your Start and End Dates accordingly.

entry.title: Re: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
Great insights!

A few questions:

  • Just curious - what kind of apps return 50k+ records in one response? Don't you hit timeout or performance issues?
  • You mentioned: "Even if SAP IS is configured for a custom page size (e.g., 1,000 or 10,000), the adapter always respects the server-side limit." I get that OData V4 only has server-side pagination, unlike OData V2 which has both options.
  • In Approach 2 - are you talking about not checking "Process in Pages" (so using built-in pagination) and adding custom splitting/pagination logic in the iFlow to deliver in chunks to the target app?

Anyway - I'm seeing again that HTTP adapter can handle things where other more specialized adapters fall short (OData V4 here, OData V2 in my case for different reasons).

entry.title: Re: Common Formula Issues in Comp Custom Fields
entry.content: Congrats on your first blog ! yes, breaking down formulas is the best tip here that can save hours: create one column for each condition in your formula then make sure it is working in each column. This way you will spot what is not working and then you can delete the extra columns used for troubleshooting. Also, do a search in the community because it is most likely that we've already provided replies on formula issues in different threads. This blog also references everything about working with date-based formulas.

entry.title: TRM- Daily Compounding calculation logic
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

I am working on an IRI with daily compound. From what I understand from the system is that when we set it as compounding interest, the system will automatically use both the SOFR + Margin rate as a single rate which will be applied to calculate the cumulative interest. However, I am trying to configure the system to where ONLY the SOFR rate is being compounded daily while the Margin rate is not. Please let me know if this possible on the system, if so, how will I configure this?

As you can see the SAP use the all-in rate (SOFR+ Margin) to calculate the interest and adds it to the based amount.  We would like to see if it's possible for the system to calculate the new base amount by only adding compounded the SOFR amount and not the margin rate. 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Adding or Removing Business Contexts
entry.content:
How to add a business context to an existing custom field 

From the very beginning, the Custom Fields Fiori app offers two ways to enable an existing custom field for additional business contexts: 

  1. By enabling a business scenario for a custom field, additional business contexts are enabled automatically. The corresponding data flows between these involved business contexts are activated, too. Therefore, custom field data is automatically transferred from one business context to the other in copy processes of the extended applications
  2.  By enabling a standard CDS view for a given key user field that exposes data from several business contexts (this can happen in cases where the CDS view represents a union of different business object nodes) 

So far, so good. But what happens if none of the options above enable you to propagate your existing custom field into your required business context? In this case, you can use our new feature. It allows you to propagate an existing custom field in any arbitrary business context, even if there are no corresponding business scenarios or union CDS views. 

Let’s have a look at how that works. We'll provide a concrete example for the new “Add Business Context” feature: 

Let’s assume you created a custom field “YY1_INVOICE_TYPE” of type code list (with a fixed set of possible code values like “Standard Invoice”, “Partial Invoice”, “Corrected Invoice”, …) for business context “Accounting: Journal Entry Item” (FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM). Afterwards it turned out that you also needed this field for business context “Group Reporting: Journal Entry Item” (FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM).  
 
As there is no business scenario and no union view available that would allow you to propagate the field into the “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” business context, in the past, the only option would have been to  

  1. create another custom field for business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” with a similar name (you can't have the same name twice) and 
  2. define (and later on maintain) the exact same code values for each of the custom fields separately 

With the new “Add Business Context” feature, this is no longer necessary. You simply can add the custom field to the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. 

In the screenshot below, you can see the custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE” that's already been created on the business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. As soon as you select this field, the “Add Business Context” button on the bottom right corner is clickable. 

Custom Field on business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” 

As soon as you click “Add Business Context”, the standard business context search help popup is shown allowing you to select an additional business context. Here, you can choose the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”. 

Choosing business context FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM 

As soon as you choose the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM”, the business context is immediately added to the custom field. 

Business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” has been added to the custom field 

That’s it. You can now publish the custom field and then you are done. 

Please note that this feature is available starting from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. 

This functionality is also available for SAP S/4HANA 2023 with support package 4. For older support packages it's available via deploying SAP note 3567408 – “Change Type of a Custom Field / Add or Remove Business Contexts to a Custom Field”.  

Next, let's take a look at how to remove business contexts from a custom field. 

How to remove a business context from a custom field 

Let’s assume that a couple of days after you enabled business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” for custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE”, it turns out that the situation has changed, and you don't need this business context any longer in this custom field. In the past, there was no way to remove a dedicated business context from a custom field.  

With the new feature, it's now possible to remove a dedicated business context from a given custom field. Within the field list shown in the Custom Fields Fiori app, you mark the entry for the business context you want to remove of custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE”. As soon as you've done that, the “Delete” button on the bottom right corner of the screen is clickable. Once you click on the down arrow within the “Delete” button, the option “Remove Field from Business Context” appears (see the screenshot below). 

“Remove Field from Business Context” option in the Custom Fields app 

As soon as you click on this option, a popup is shown asking you whether you really want to delete the field from this business context (see the screenshot below).  

Confirmation popup “Do you want to remove selected field from business context” 

Once you click on “Delete”, the selected business context is removed from the field and the publishing process for this change is automatically triggered. 

With this, you are done. You successfully removed the business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” from custom field “YY1_INVOICETYPE” 

Custom field successfully removed from business context “FINCS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” 

Congratulations! 
Please note that in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editions, a removal of a business context from a custom field is only possible if the adding of the business context to this custom field has not been released with a software collection so far. Afterwards, you can still delete the entire custom field, but you can no longer choose to only remove the business context you've added. 

This functionality is also available for SAP S/4HANA 2023 with support package 4. For older support packages, it's available via deploying SAP note 3567408 – “Change Type of a Custom Field / Add or Remove Business Contexts to a Custom Field”.  

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Christian Fuhlbruegge(ChristianFuhlbruegge),  and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions. 

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

Other related blog posts: 

  1. Key User Custom Fields: When to use what type of code list 
  1. SAP S/4HANA Key User Extensibility: Custom field with context-dependent value help 
  1. SAP S/4HANA Key User Extensibility powered by Embedded Steampunk: Custom Field with ABAP implemented Value Help 
  1. Enrich SAP S/4HANA Key User Custom fields with Intent-Based Navigation

entry.title: Trying to get YTD with 1 month offset SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello all,

I am kind of new to SAC and it's my first time posting, so if my question is kind of simple, I apologize and apreciate the help. I'm trying to get a Year to Date with a month offset look back direction of 1 month in a Restricted Account (Sorry, confusing). Right now I am offsetting by 1 month and looking back a year or almost a year. But this is not what I want or was trying to achieve.

This is my current Range. I don't want to get any months from the year before, just the year I'm filtered for (2025). I'm using the months in 2024 because I know they have no data, but once they do, this filter will not be what I need. But I've been trying to make it work and just can't. I need it to be just from January to the month before the filter (in this case, September, since the filter is in October). I'm trying to do a Waterfall Chart that compares the accumulated value from January to the month before the filter (So Jan-Sept) to the accumulated value from January till the month chosen in the filter (Jan-Oct).

entry.title: Fast-track AI-driven Insights with Zero-Copy Data Access between SAP BDC and Google BigQuery
entry.content:
SAP launched SAP Datasphere with its business data fabric architecture and open data ecosystem in 2023, with Google as one of its first partners. Since then, we’ve continued helping customers drive innovation with a data and analytics strategy that unifies SAP data and analytics with the strengths of Google Cloud’s BigQuery platform.  

Building on this partnership, we recently announced SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Connect for Google BigQuery at SAP Connect 2025, further strengthening our collaboration and enabling secure, zero-copy data access to curated SAP data products directly from BigQuery. SAP BDC Connect for Google BigQuery is planned to be generally available by the end of H1 2026. 

With SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery, organizations can build a business data fabric and connect their existing Google BigQuery environments to #SAP Business Data Cloud—offering data and AI teams real-time access to semantically rich SAP data products without the duplication or operational burden of multiple ETL pipelines. SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery will also be bidirectional, so organizations can break silos and democratize data with an ecosystem of business-ready data products exchanged between SAP BDC and Google Cloud Cortex Framework in BigQuery. This milestone reflects a clear architectural transformation, unlocking the potential of enterprise data for analytics and AI innovation. 

 In this blog, we take a sneak-peek into the technology behind this integration and offer prescriptive guidance with reference architectures for building seamless data integration between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google Cloud’s data and AI solutions. 

Fig 1 : SAP BDC – GBQ Integration reference architecture.  

SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery will enable seamless, secure data sharing between SAP BDC and Google BigQuery—simplifying customer landscapes and accelerating AI-driven insights and innovation.  

Third-party data, such as Google Cloud’s Weather, Trends, Geo, and Ads, can then be effortlessly integrated and harmonized with valuable SAP data like finance and supply chain. Leveraging open data protocols and advanced data fabric architectures, this approach will simplify data sharing and unify access to information across multiple systems in a heterogenous landscape. The result will be a centrally governed, holistic data environment that supports efficient analytics and AI/ML-driven use cases—all built on industry-standard open protocols.  

Challenges addressed by SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery:  

This new zero-copy integration with BigQuery aims to solve challenges caused by data duplication copies.  

  • Loss of governance: Data governance becomes a major challenge once data is replicated and siloed into multiple disparate systems.  
  • Loss of valuable semantics: Data extracted from business applications loses its critical semantics and business context, making it incredibly difficult to rebuild accurately and leading to issues in data quality. 
  • High total cost of ownership (TCO) : Managing ETL pipelines with expensive third-party tools adds operational complexity and overhead, elevating the total cost of ownership (TCO) across the data landscape. 
  • Innovation delays: Complex and fragile data pipelines hinder organizational agility, delays the delivery of actionable business insights, and restrict the pace of AI innovation and data-driven initiatives. 

Key differentiating capabilities that will be introduced by the SAP BDC Connect for BigQuery architecture include: 

  • Access to AI-ready data: Accelerate AI-driven insights by combining Google Cloud's Vertex AI capabilities and analytics tools with curated, AI-ready SAP data products securely shared and governed directly from SAP Business Data Cloud.  
  • Unified Data View: Deliver a harmonized view by integrating SAP data and third-party data across Google BigQuery and SAP Business Data Cloud without duplication. Build a unified, semantically rich data foundation to fuel next-gen data and AI/ML workloads using SAP Joule, Google Vertex AI, and Google Cortex framework. 
  • Bi-directional data sharing: Share data products bi-directionally between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google BigQuery via their respective catalogs. This enables interoperability and re-use of these blended data sets  and derived data products . 
  •  Delta Sharing protocol: Leverage bidirectional data integration between SAP BDC and BigQuery, powered by the combination of industry open standards such as Delta Sharing open data protocol and other open table formats. This enables real-time interoperability across different computing platforms, cloud environments, and applications without duplicating data. 
  • Opens up flexible infrastructure choices: Leverage the highly scalable infrastructure of Google BigQuery , and powerful enterprise analytics capabilities of SAP Business Data Cloud to handle large volumes of data and complex analytics workloads. Share data products from Google BigQuery back to SAP BDC for analytics and planning in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI solutions with SAP Business AI as well.  
  • Governed and secure data exchange: Provide a secure and governed experience with enhanced control over data shared via centralized access, managed by data stewardship roles. BDC Connect leverages security protocols such as mutual Transport Layer Security (mTLS) and OpenID Connect (OIDC) to ensure safe data exchanges 
  • Increased scalability and data exchange speed: With the zero-copy integration,  the bottleneck of slow data transfers (as seen with data federation architecture) will be solved SAP BDC Connect that offers efficient data sharing at great scale than before.    

 The technical integration (SAP BDC Connect for Google BigQuery) enables powerful, AI-driven use cases across these business functions, detailed in the sources as strategic focuses for the partnership.

 

Business Function Use Cases Enabled 
Supply Chain & Operations Predictive Inventory Optimization: Combining live SAP inventory data with marketing campaign data (e.g., TikTok, Meta, Google Ads) and external signals like weather data or Google Trends for demand forecasting. 
 AI-Powered Logistics: Integrating SAP order and fulfillment data with external data (like GPS/traffic) to optimize delivery routes and predict delays.
 Enhanced Demand Forecasting: Using machine learning to analyze historical SAP sales data combined with market trends and promotions. 

Marketing 

Cross-Channel Campaign Optimization: Combining SAP customer sales history with audience data (e.g., LiveRamp) and campaign performance from Google Ads, YouTube, Meta, and TikTok to optimize spend and ROI. 
 Personalized Marketing Campaigns: Using enriched SAP customer and product data to create highly personalized campaigns on platforms like Google Ads and social media. 
Sales & Service 360-Degree Customer View: Consolidating customer data from SAP (billing, service history) with sales data (Salesforce) and service interactions (ServiceNow). 
Manufacturing Unified IT/OT Data for AI: Ingesting granular asset-level data from the shop floor (OT data) and sensor data and combining it with enterprise (IT) data for Manufacturing to improve productivity. 
 Production Optimization: Gaining cross-enterprise intelligence by tracking marketing campaigns to inform product demand, production, and staffing. 
Finance & Analytics Build Grounded, Trustworthy AI: Ensuring that Google BigQuery AI models and agents operate on the most current and complete view of the business using real-time SAP data. 
Sustainability ESG Reporting and Optimization: Integrating sustainability data from SAP with other external data sources to create a unified view for comprehensive reporting and using AI to analyze energy consumption or carbon emissions. 

 

Enhancing and scaling use cases with SAP BDC connect for Google BigQuery  

This expanded partnership also allows us to enhance previous SAP Datasphere and BigQuery use cases. While FedML successfully enabled machine-learning use cases on Google Cloud Platform using SAP data, further scaling was necessary to support data at larger volumes. Users could also replicate data to Google BigQuery using SAP Datasphere replication flows.  For example, analyzing historical SAP sales data alongside market trends and promotions typically required either replicating the data needed—complex, costly, and time-consuming—or using connector-based data federation, which is faster but less scalable.  

Now, SAP BDC Connect for Google BigQuery provides a simpler, secure, and scalable option with one-click, zero-copy data sharing via BDC catalog. This eliminates the need for data duplication , reduces data access delays usually seen with federated access, and ensures secure and governed data access (which was missing with service user-based connectors). 

In summary, the zero-copy architecture enabled by BDC Connect for Google BigQuery addresses business challenges with greater speed, lower cost, improved quality, enhanced security, and unprecedented scale. 

Credits

The above reference architectures are the results of teamwork and contributions from both SAP and Google. I would like to thank the following SAP team members for their contribution to this content  : Kevin Poskitt, Katryn Cheng, Mariusz Cisek, San Tran And  Sivakumar N,  Anirban Majumdar, Haridas Nair for their support and guidance. We also extend special thanks to the Google team members who helped assemble the guiding use-case list.
 
If you have any questions, please leave a comment below or contact us at paa@sap.com.

entry.title: Budget EAC/ ETC for entreprise projects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

As part of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  project, I would like to present the identified open points, the investigations carried out, and the potential solutions I have considered. I would also like to know if there are standard alternatives to address these needs

Identified Issues

  • Unavailability of EAC* (Estimate at Completion) and ETC* (Estimate to Complete) functionalities for enterprise projects in SAP Cloud Public
  • Finding a solution to manually enter the initial budget budget without using the CSV file (scope item 1H

Investigation and Proposed Solutions

For the first point (EAC/ETC):

  • Excel: Export budget data from SAP Public Cloud and calculate EAC and ETC using formulas.
  • Custom CDS Views: Create custom views to extract the necessary data (committed costs, remaining costs) and perform calculations outside SAP.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Build dashboards incorporating EAC and ETC calculations.
  • Adding specific fields: Create two new data points (EAC and ETC) in reporting, which would require custom development.
  • Implementing service projects: Considered as an option, but raises integration issues with production and logistics.

For the second point (initial budget):

  • We have only found the solution via CSV upload.

Questions

Are there standard functionalities or recommended best practices in SAP Public Cloud to:

  • Calculate and display EAC and ETC in enterprise projects?
  • Enter the initial budget manually without using the CSV file?

Thanks

entry.title: Issue with Withholding Tax Codes Not Appearing in DRC Configure Value Mapping – Colombia Localizatio
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We are currently implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Colombia localization), including Document and Report Compliance (DRC) for electronic invoicing with the DIAN.

The communication channel with the tax authority is working correctly — invoices are successfully sent and return with an Approved status.

However, we are facing an issue specifically in the Configure Value Mapping area.

🔍 Issue Summary

In the Configure Value Mapping app, only the VAT Tax Codes (e.g., codes starting with A* or V* for sales and purchasing VAT) are visible and available for mapping to the Tax Code ID required by the DIAN.

But the withholding tax codes configured in our system do not appear in the Value Mapping list.

These include:

  • RETE-IVA

  • RETE-ICA

  • ICA

  • Self-withholding (Autorretección) types

  • Other withholding tax codes configured internally (our customer uses codes starting with 8*)

These withholding tax codes are correctly configured in the system, work in the accounting simulations, and are already being used in multiple test scenarios.
However, they do not show up in the Configure Value Mapping app, which prevents us from linking them to the Tax Code IDs specified by the tax authority.

📄 Impact

When generating the electronic invoice PDF, all fields related to withholding taxes appear empty.

Since the withholding tax codes cannot be mapped (because they do not appear in the Value Mapping catalog), the DRC processing does not include them in the XML/PDF output.

❓ Question for the SAP Community

Where in CBC or within the Document and Report Compliance configuration should Colombia withholding tax codes be mapped so that they appear in Configure Value Mapping?

Is there an additional configuration step or specific prerequisite for withholding tax codes to appear as eligible values in the mapping catalog?
Currently, only VAT tax codes are being recognized by the system as “Tax Code ID” candidates.

We would appreciate guidance on:

  • Whether Colombia withholding tax codes are expected to appear in Value Mapping

  • If they must be created or exposed through a different configuration artifact

  • Whether any CBC configuration node must be enabled for withholding tax mapping

  • Or if withholding taxes are not supported for mapping in the current DRC scope for Colombia

We will attach screenshots showing where VAT codes are visible, and where withholding tax codes (8*) do not appear.

Thank you in advance for your help and insights.

entry.title: Prompt Engineering: Unlocking Hidden Power for Enterprise AI Success
entry.content:
Gaps in Prompt Design Derail the User Experience

What happens when gaps in prompt design or user intent recognition turns everyday AI interactions into a dead‑end waste of time?

Have you ever experienced this type of situation?

For example, I recently tried to claim a rebate for a kitchen appliance, but the company’s AI assistant misinterpreted my request and left me stuck with irrelevant FAQs. The issue was poor prompt design. With proper prompt engineering, the assistant could have recognized my rebate request and guided me to the correct, enabled form. A smarter workflow would have turned a dead end into a faster way to get my rebate money.

What fun!

This experience underscores a critical truth: when prompts fail to capture real‑world users’ intent, the customer experience collapses.

For business and IT users working with AI, this isn’t just a consumer inconvenience, it’s a wake‑up call. Prompt engineering is more than a technical capability; it’s the discipline of shaping interactions so that AI systems understand nuance, adapt to context, and deliver meaningful results.

Whether in customer service troubleshooting, enterprise workflows (agentic AI), or customer engagement, the quality of prompts directly determines the quality of the user experience.

In this age of AI agents and assistants, refining prompts is no longer optional; it is essential for building trust, driving efficiency, enabling scalable automation, and achieving successful outcomes.

Reducing AI Project Failures - Understanding Prompt Engineering

Prompt engineering is the art and science of designing inputs that guide AI models to produce desired outputs. By framing instructions accurately, organizations can harness AI to generate relevant, high-quality responses.

According to a RAND report, 80% of AI project failures stem from poor human to AI communication. Misunderstandings between business and IT teams about goals, data, and capabilities are the most common cause of failure. Companies that master prompt engineering achieve significantly higher ROI compared to those relying on basic or ad hoc prompting (1).

In short: success doesn’t come from the technology alone; it comes from how we communicate with it.

Why It Matters

Prompt engineering is no longer a fringe capability and skill. It is becoming a critical organizational capability embedded into everyday business functions.

According to Market Research Future (MRFR), the prompt engineering market was valued at $2.195 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow to $32.78 billion by 2035, with a staggering 27.86% CAGR (2).

SAP Prompt Engineering Adoption

Prompt engineering transforms vague queries into precise instructions, guiding AI toward accurate, consistent, and actionable outputs. With AI agents and assistants like SAP’s Joule, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, and OpenAI’s ChatGPT, organizations recognize that prompt engineering is essential to maximize AI’s potential and align outcomes with business goals.

SAP has embedded prompt engineering into Joule, powered by the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and Launchpad (part of the SAP Business Technology Platform) and supported by SAP’s AI Foundation, delivering enterprise‑grade accuracy and trust with Large Language Models (LLMs).

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP announced a proprietary Prompt Optimizer built with the company, Not Diamond. This optimizer enables enterprises to migrate and adapt prompts across multiple LLMs, supporting consistency, accelerating adoption, and improving the user experience across diverse AI systems (3).

Not Diamond envisions “a multi‑model AI future, with thousands of foundation models, millions of fine‑tuned variants, and billions of custom inference engines running on top of them.” Their infrastructure routes, governs, and scales prompts across these systems, ensuring flexibility and trust.

This partnership confirms prompt engineering as an important, core enterprise requirement, bridging business strategy with technology capabilities for responsible AI.

Best of Prompt Engineering Capabilities

Prompt engineering serves as the strategic layer that transforms raw AI capabilities into business value, delivering a range of benefits including:

  1. Clarifies Intent – Ensures AI understands user goals, reducing miscommunication and aligning outputs with business needs.
  2. Customer Engagement & Personalization – Crafts prompts that drive tailored chatbot interactions, outreach, and recommendations, fostering loyalty and satisfaction.
  3. Structures Outputs – Guides AI to deliver usable formats (tables, lists, reports, narratives) for clarity and consistency.
  4. Improves Efficiency & Operational Automation – Minimizes unnecessary token usage, accelerates turnaround, and empowers agentic AI to automate repetitive workflows such as reporting, summarization, and FAQ handling.
  5. Adds Domain Context – Embeds industry‑specific language, governance and compliance rules, approved product names, synonyms, and brand tone for relevance.
  6. Supports Scalability Across Teams – Builds reusable prompt libraries and frameworks that allow consistent enterprise‑wide adoption without reinventing workflows.
  7. Content Quality & Consistency – Ensures outputs are brand‑aligned, accurate, and emotionally resonant across all channels.
  8. Optimizes Across Models – With tools like Not Diamond’s Prompt Optimizer, prompts can be migrated and adapted across Copilot, Gemini, ChatGPT, Joule, and other LLMs.
  9. Enhanced Accuracy & Decision‑Making – Produces precise, consistent outputs and extracts actionable intelligence quickly to support better business decisions.

By uniting these capabilities, prompt engineering becomes the foundation for trustworthy, scalable, and business‑aligned AI success.

Short on Time? Who Manages Prompt Engineering

Prompt engineering isn’t just the domain of IT or developers; business roles like product managers, business analysts, marketing, communications, operations, UX/CX designers, content strategists, and other lines of business are equally critical.

For example, product managers align prompts with business goals, analysts map workflows, designers ensure intuitive user experiences, and strategists refine language and tone. Together, they make AI outputs reliable and customer‑centric.

Also, a dedicated, focused part‑time prompt engineering consultant can help jumpstart this process by auditing the current status, delivering best practices, and establishing governance standards in collaboration with IT and key stakeholders.

In a fast paced, short-handed, busy work environment, these prompt optimization specialists can provide support by providing focus and discipline, coaching key stakeholders with standard operation procedures (SOPs), monitoring performance, and refining prompts as business needs evolve to help ensure AI systems remain accurate, consistent, and trusted across the enterprise.

Final Thoughts

Prompt engineering is no longer a niche skill or technical curiosity; it has become a core business capability that drives efficiency, compliance, and innovation. Organizations that embrace it gain a competitive edge, while those that neglect it risk wasted investments and inconsistent results.

By embedding prompt engineering as a business standard, integrated into workflows through enterprise‑wide libraries, governance, and automated refinement, companies can optimize AI strategies to keep pace with evolving models, regulations, and customer expectations.

The future of enterprise AI will not be defined by those who merely explore prompts, but by those who master them, transforming raw model potential into trusted, scalable business value.

And as a result, users can save time by getting answers versus gaps and dead ends.

---
Your Comments are Appreciated!

➡️.Interested to hear your experiences when prompting works and doesn't work from a business and IT perspective!!! 
If you are new to prompt engineering, what are your impressions as a result of reading this blog?
Please take a moment to post them below... 
Thanks!!!

---

About the Author

Rich Blumberg is a long time SAP Community member and contributor. For 20+ years he's been an SAP consultant working with SAP ecosystem organizations around the globe. He's the President of World Sales Solutions, LLC, (WSS) a business development and low-code no-code services company. He has published two acclaimed Amazon books, Job Seeking Warriors – A Mentors Guide to Winning and Novi’s Journey to the Magic Garden. In his spare time, he is a Drexel University Alumni Board of Governors Emeritus volunteer, ENGin English tutor for Ukrainian citizens, and an aspiring guitar player.

---

Footnotes

  1. RAND Corporation, “The Root Causes of Failure for Artificial Intelligence Projects and How They Can Succeed: Avoiding the Anti‑Patterns of AI,” (August 2024)
  2. Market Research Future, “Prompt Engineering Market Size, Share, Trends, Analysis 2035.” Published (October 2025)
  3. Press Release, “Not Diamond Launches Prompt Adaptation, an Agentic System for Multi-Model Enterprise AI” (May 2025)

entry.title: How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes
entry.content:
How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes

Read the original article here

Expectations of the potential impact of AI have never been higher. But so far, most projects have only produced incremental improvements in isolated areas. So, what do you have to do to get AI to deliver material change across your business? The answer lies in preparing your processes and data—getting them into a condition where AI can use them to deliver on its promise of radical transformation. In this thought provoking article, two AI experts from SAP explain what’s involved, where to get started, and which SAP solutions can help you really put AI to work.

About the authors:

Jürgen Butsmann is part of the SAP Cloud ERP Product Marketing team responsible for AI in the context of SAP S/4HANA, finance and digital supply chain. Jürgen has been with SAP for more than 26 years.  He is a recognized expert for SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP .

Terry Penner is part of the SAP BTP product marketing team, focused on SAP BTP for Cloud ERP. He has more than 25 years of technical and business experience in the SAP platform and analytics, including working directly on hundreds of customer implementations and presenting on SAP technology topics at conferences around the world.

 

The challenges in reaching AI’s potential

Business leaders believe AI has the potential to transform their organizations.  They see it accelerating cycle times, reducing errors, performing processes automatically, and yielding insights. Their initial experiments and projects have reinforced this expectation by delivering productivity improvements, albeit in isolated areas.

However, return on investment has so far been disappointing and IT teams are finding it challenging to scale AI beyond point solutions. They’re also nervous for ethical and security reasons about exposing their proprietary business data to public large language  models (LLMs).

Observations from customers

The discussions we’ve been having with SAP customers have revealed these common challenges IT leaders face in realizing AI’s potential.

  • Insecure architecture. Using public LLMs alone is not always reliable. AI really needs to use the organization’s own business data. But exposing corporate data to LLMs raises security and ethical issues.
  • Fragmented systems. Applying AI to a process that is contained within a single system is relatively easy. But most real business processes span multiple departments and systems. Often these applications and their data are not integrated which prevents AI from carrying out business processes end to end.
  • No single semantic layer. Enterprise applications today, whether SAP or non-SAP, all have differences in their data structures. Data transformation and harmonization are necessary to allow the sharing of transactional data, and for analytical processes and AI functions to  take place.
  • One-way data transformation. Data warehousing, as practiced by SAP and by other vendors in the past, focused on extraction  and one-way transformation, storage, and processing of data, decoupled from original data structures and business process context. Effective, enterprise-wide AI, however, requires two-way transformation and re-integration of data into business processes as they run.

What organizations need

AI agent networks need a solid data foundation  if they are to process queries across systems effectively. The organization’s data structures—its master data and system architecture—need to be harmonized so AI can understand the different systems in a consistent and accurate way.

When processes are integrated, consistent data can be stored in the systems. Integrating systems and maintaining consistent data will overcome the problem of isolated, fragmented systems and allow AI to execute end-to-end business processes.

 

SAP’s strategy for scalable AI

SAP’s approach to enabling organizations to scale their use of AI is to facilitate the integration of systems and business processes, and the harmonization of business data, within a secure AI architecture.

The key components of this are:

  • Secure AI architecture
  • Solutions for scaling AI
  • Joule, the integrated digital assistant
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for data harmonization
  • SAP Business Technology Platform as the platform for Joule, SAP BDC, AI Hub, and process

Secure AI architecture

Figure 1: A common sub-optimal approach

Figure 2: Exposing corporate data to LLMs is not recommended

SAP's secure architecture allows AI to understand your business safely.

The process works like this:

  • The user queries their digital assistant, Joule.
  • The digital assistant uses both the LLM and the vector database to create a refined prompt. The technical process is decoupled from the proprietary business data (a technique known as masking) to prevent the data being exposed outside the organization.
  • The refined prompt then requests data from cloud ERP and other proprietary systems, such as the  SAP Foundation Model.
  • Data is returned to the digital assistant via the vector database and the results are clustered and explained by the LLM.
  • The digital assistant then presents the final answer to the user.

 

SAP solutions for scaling AI

As an SAP customer, you may be familiar with our strategic architecture. Working from the top down, we call out here three elements which are material to scaling AI.

Figure 4: SAP strategic architecture

Joule

Joule is SAP’s agent orchestrator and ubiquitous user interface for AI. It is embedded throughout SAP Business Suite solutions incl. SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private. Joule skills perform simple repetitive tasks within one application. Joule Agents give context-aware access to a system  of AI agents, that can perform more complex end-to-end processes across multiple systems— provided those systems have been integrated and their data’s been harmonized.

Agents can work within or separately from Joule. They can call and quest other agents in the background without having to be triggered manually. This is done transparently in Joule to keep the human in the loop.

SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Business Technology Platform supports SAP Business Suite solutions. It provides a foundation for AI and data analytics and includes integration and extension solutions.

  • SAP Integration Suite contains more than 3,800 prebuilt integrations and APIs for connecting business processes across systems more easily.
  • SAP Build solutions help you create extensions and automate processes across SAP and  non-SAP solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a single semantic layer across applications and enables the harmonization of data. This is essential not only for AI to work effectively, but also to share transactional data and facilitate analytical processes. SAP BDC uses data products which are prebuilt multi-layered structures (which may include extensions of clean-core compliant data structures) for executing function-specific queries and processes across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Having a common data platform across your enterprise allows AI to utilize your proprietary  business data within a secure environment. The data products come as part of so-called intelligent applications which contains applications built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, as well as other domain content.

Customers can always extend the data layer, for example by defining custom data products.

Advantages of SAP Business Data Cloud

In some cases, operational data has been used for executing AI functions or analytical and planning operations without applying data products from SAP BDC. In the past, data storage for these operations took place in BTP, as the AI hub is located there as well as in SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA. But what was missing was the delivery of a common and harmonized data storage concept across all SAP applications.

SAP BDC makes it possible to establish a common architecture where data is extracted, transformed, and returned to SAP Business Suite applications, creating harmonized data storage. A common data platform across your organization will provide the data foundation for AI to connect securely to specialized, enterprise-specific data.

SAP BDC also allows for SAP-managed deployment, maintenance, and facilitation of data processing and transformation from the source system to SAP BDC. These services are part of the data products of the intelligent applications.

SAP Business Suite provides APIs between different SAP and non-SAP applications, allowing the data exchange needed for integrated execution of business processes.

Prioritizing the establishment of a common layer also influences changes to local data structures. The data required to support integrated business process and other cross-system operations is held directly within the source systems, with no need for a secondary harmonization layer. This is very well aligned with the clean core concept.

 

What does it mean for me?

Do I need all this before my AI will work?

No, but the more elements you have, the more value you get.

  • If you only have SAP BDC, you’ll have access to harmonized data—but you won’t yet have connected business processes across applications.
  • If you use SAP BTP solutions such as SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build to create integrations and extensions, you’ll be able to join up business processes across applications—but not harmonize their data.
  • If you use SAP BDC and SAP BTP solutions together, you can integrate business processes across systems and harmonize their data. A derived harmonization model is intended to be generated by the system using APIs to produce a fully integrated model for cross-system reporting and AI data usage. Then Joule Agents can use that harmonized data to orchestrate end-to-end business processes across multiple systems automatically.

Are there other ways of doing this?

Yes, but they’re not as good. Some of our customers use third party data harmonization solutions for cross-system analytical use cases.

The difference with SAP’s AI-first strategy is that it is always aware of the actual business context and reintegrates results data back into the business process. This is essential if AI agents are to make use of that data in cross-department, cross-system use cases.

SAP’s integrated suite of ERP and business applications, together with our data management solution, and our integration and extension solutions, is unique in the marketplace at present.

How can I move from isolated use cases to enterprise-wide AI?

Basically, you need to offer AI that people can trust.

To achieve trust, you need a secure AI architecture along with integrated processes and harmonized data. When you have these, people will trust the AI model. Then they’ll come to view it as reliable and adopt it for day-to-day, end-to-end business processes across the organization.

 

How this approach can help you - a worked example

Automating financial close

One of the most attractive use cases for AI is to modernize a business process which occurs in every business and which, if automated, would deliver significant productivity and cost benefits. The process in question is the financial close.

It’s a classic challenge. The data required sits in multiple systems, such as ERP, CRM, tax engines, and payroll—which aren’t integrated. The data is also in incompatible formats. Both these mean that considerable manual work is required in extracting and reconciling the data. All of which adds up to time, cost, and stress at the end of every accounting period.

With systems integrated using SAP Integration Suite, and data harmonized using SAP Business Data Cloud, Joule Agents can be built to help perform financial close processes optimally—always leaving knowledgeable human beings to make the final decision.

SAP’s enablers of autonomous finance can expedite financial close processes and deliver material cost savings. The Canadian energy company, Suncor, achieved a reduction of US$20,000 in month-end closing costs and a 98% reduction in time to reconcile ICT postings using SAP Business AI and SAP Build Process Automation.

Figure 5: Integration flow diagram of a connected financial close process in SAP Integration Suite.

 

How do I get started?

To summarize, our two key recommendations are to modernize your data and integrate your processes.

Modernize your data

Evolve your data strategy from using harmonized historical data extracted from business systems, to using current data generated in the process of executing business processes.

Aim to make multiple data sources accessible to AI, including a combination of business data from multiple internal systems and external data.

Integrate your processes

Move away from older integration technologies that are not cloud aware, such as process integration or process orchestration, to standardizing on SAP Integration Suite with thousands of prebuilt integrations.

Adopt a consistent method across the organization for connecting your processes so that when you build AI agents to orchestrate them across multiple systems, users get a consistent experience.

 

Immediate next steps

Ask your SAP account manager to set up a conversation with one of our enterprise architects. You can discuss where you are now, where you want to be, and draw up a plan for getting there.

In the meantime, find out more about:

  • SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP’s vision for autonomous finance

entry.title: Move-to-RISE Project – Clarifications Required for SolMan, CHaRM, Hostnames, and Transport
entry.content:
Dear SAP Expert Team,

We are currently preparing a Move-to-RISE migration for our customer.
The SAP landscape is fully managed by SAP Solution Manager, and CHaRM is active for all SAP systems.

Because CHaRM must remain fully functional throughout the migration, Solution Manager will remain on-premise until the landscape has been moved to SAP RISE. SolMan itself will only be migrated .

To prepare the technical architecture, we kindly request official confirmation on the following points:

 

Hostnames & Logical System Names :

To keep CHaRM, TMS, LMDB, and managed-system configuration stable, please clarify:

  1. Can SAP RISE keep the same SAP system logical names (EXP: S4HCLNT100, S4HCLNT200)?
  2. Can SAP RISE keep the same virtual hostnames for each SAP system
    (to avoid reconfiguring CHaRM, RFCs, and TMS)?
  3. If hostnames must change, what impact should we expect on CHaRM history, projects, cycles, and tracks?
  4. Does SAP provide a standard procedure to map old hostnames to new RISE hostnames?

Transport Directory (/usr/sap/trans) :

Our current CHaRM/TMS setup uses a shared on-premise /usr/sap/trans transport domain.

Please confirm SAP RISE policies:

  1. Is it allowed to continue using the on-premise /usr/sap/trans directory for systems running in RISE during the migration period, until the landscape is fully moved?
  2. If not:
    • Does SAP RISE provide a cloud,transport directory for TMS?
    • Can we operate with a dual /trans setup (on-prem + RISE) during the transition ?
    • Is synchronization between the two transport directories supported or recommended?

Additionally, in case synchronization between the on-premise /trans and the RISE /trans is required:

    • Beyond cofiles and datafiles, must transport logs also be synchronized to ensure CHaRM continues to function properly ?
    • If RISE requires a new transport domain:
  1. How can we preserve CHaRM history and avoid losing change logs?
  2. How can we maintain end-to-end consistency until Solution Manager is migrated?

CHaRM Configuration & Managed Systems :

To ensure CHaRM remains fully operational during the project, please confirm:

  1. If RISE systems use different hostnames or a new /trans directory,
    will any CHaRM historical data, task lists, cycles, or change documents be lost?
  2. Is there a SAP-recommended procedure for:
    • Reintegrating systems into SolMan with a new hostname without losing history?
    • Updating LMDB/SLD entries safely during or after the migration?
  3. Are there official SAP Notes or guides covering:
    • Running CHaRM with a hybrid on-prem + RISE landscape
    • Migrating Solution Manager to RISE
    • Preserving historical data, cycles, retrofit configuration, and change documents

Thank you in advance for your help and support

entry.title: Outbound Delivery for Return PO Allows Quantity Higher Than Available Stock
entry.content:
Issue Description

In a Return Purchase Order (Return to Vendor), the system allows creation of an outbound delivery with a quantity greater than the available stock.
This occurs even though the actual physical stock is lower.

Example:

  • Return PO created for 100 pcs
  • Actual stock available: 50 pcs
  • System still allows creating outbound delivery for 100 pcs

Is there a possibility to prevent creation of an outbound delivery for quantities exceeding the available stock or at least issue a warning/error message?

entry.title: BiWhy – All-in-One Support Tool. Feature Overview (Brief Version)
entry.content:
Disclaimer:
BiWhy is available again for FREE to everyone on biwhy.net

BiWhy is a comprehensive general-purpose (not BOBJ only) support tool with a strong focus on features designed to enhance SAP BusinessObjects monitoring, administration, and troubleshooting, addressing the most important and frequently used aspects missing from standard solutions or improving their usability.

BiWhy: Motivations and Approach (see below)

 Feature Overview

1. Host / OS-Level Monitoring
Monitors system-level and process-level CPU, memory, disk, network...
 
2. BOBJ Metrics Monitoring
Provides deep analysis of BOBJ server metrics using trees, tables, charts, filters, automated checks, landscape summaries, and multi-system logon configurations.
 
3. CMS DB Analysis
Analyzes CMS DB content and history, including object quantity and size allocations; compares snapshots to identify changes or promotion issues, with flexible filtering and optimized CMS DB object fetching.
 
4. CMS DB Queries (Super-Advanced CMC Admin Tools)
Fetches and displays CMS DB data in trees and tables with detailed property analysis; provides query libraries, Excel export, parent-child flattening, automated ID-to-name resolution, calculated measures, and offline analysis.
 
5. CMS Actions
Executes actions on CMS objects (update, delete, move, pause/resume jobs, etc.) based on flexible CMS queries; actions are easily extendable.
 
6. Rights Analysis
Evaluates effective and explicit rights for selected objects, including recursive checks across entire folder structures, with filtering by a specified principal.
 
7. Audit DB / General SQL Client
As a JDBC client that allows running any SELECT queries (with DELETE/UPDATE disabled for extra safety), testing fetch-array-size performance, interrupting long fetches, and reviewing select/fetch statistics.
 
As Audit DB browser, it is 10–100 times faster than WEBI Reports on Audit Universe. Maybe I’m biased, but even before BiWhy I always preferred using a direct DB client to work with the Audit DB, especially during escalations.
Setup is easy – you only need a JDBC connection string.
Shows all available filters, assists with building queries, resolves IDs to names, and drills down into event details.
Tip: always check ERROR events.
 
8. Sessions
User/session analysis – divergence, durations, long durations, multiple concurrent sessions, timeouts.
Session administration – mass-kill operations.
 
9. Publications
Publication analysis – durations, duration per recipient, count, source reports.
 
10. GLF Logs
End-to-end analysis with automated time-consumer detection, grouping, flow trees by workflow or host/server, mining, statistics, RFC and Business Transaction views, and interactive cross-linked visualizations.
The idea was to fill the gaps in FlexiLogReader.
 
11. Java Threads
Thread dumps analysis – takes advantage of additional information provided in thread dumps by SAP JVM (CPU, files, network, elapsed time).
Groups threads by their type, allows quickly detect CPU or Memory abuser or pin particular thread to traffic or opened files. Frequently it is good enough proxy for system-load picture.
Allows walk on stack changes and charts thread states (waiting, running, etc.).
 
12. Java Stacks
Simplifies stacks for readability – show/hide parameters or packages.
Compares stacks to highlight common parts and points of divergence.
 
13. Java Jars
Indexes all JARs in your system once and lets you search which JAR a given class is loaded from.
 
14. Java JMX
Monitors JMX metrics across multiple processes/hosts and presents them in a tree with table and chart analysis. Much more convenient than Oracle’s JMX tool, in my view.
Useful for any Java app monitoring or configuration check.
Supports BOBJ JMX connections – similar to Wily Introscope, though BiWhy’s BOBJ Metrics (via the BOBJ API) are more convenient.
Possible future development: modifying parameters without restarting the application (e.g., Tomcat). I needed it only once, so this feature is on hold.
 
15. AO Logs
Analysis for Office logs – e2e/net time, grouping by type, tree view, tables, flow and other charts.
Requires updating to the current BiWhy controls to enable full embedded analytics.
 
16. XML
Browsing – filters empty/zeroed attributes and duplicates, shortens paths, supports search. Especially useful for large XML analysis.
Comparison – highlights differences and hides common parts; useful, for example, for configuration comparison.
 
17. Files
Indexes directories and compares servers or environments by hiding common files and filtering out nonessential files (logs, etc.).
Provides tree and table analysis – count, size, modification. Allows fast search, much faster than the OS when folders are not indexed.
 
18. Text Tools
Growing set of common text-analysis operations.
Compares lists.
Compare file lines – very useful for configurations spread across multiple files.
Unique entries and counts.
Includes converters.
 
19. OS Command
Runs system commands at given intervals, filters output, and provides quick interactive analysis.
 
20. Tools (File Collection, Zip, GC)
Designed to collect BOBJ logs from multiple hosts – configure once, then collect in seconds when needed.
Configuration is auto-assisted: you only provide missing details (e.g., Tomcat hosts), and BiWhy generates file-location templates.
 
Truly collecting everything for comprehensive analysis — or to keep SAP Support happy — spans many directories and is rarely done because explaining where to collect from is too time-consuming, and the resulting files are usually poorly structured.
 
Supports filtering by modification time or extension, so you gather only what you need.
Shows statistics and progress for collected files.
Includes zipping for convenience.
 
Can also serve as a general file collector — for example, to gather all *.jar, *.xml, *.properties, etc. files.
 
21. BiWhy Table (Embedded Analytics)
Flexible table with row/column filters, grouping, statistical analysis, useful renderers (duration, bytes, etc.), and a set of frequently used flexible charts.
In some aspects, better than Excel – no row limits, multi-column handling. Some analytical tools also struggle with long-string handling.
 
22. Analytics
Imports external data into BiWhy Table for further analysis.
Supports saved import templates (separators, escape characters, time formats).
Especially useful for analyzing Tomcat access logs.
 
23. HAR Logs (Beta)
Basic HAR-file analysis. Development was frozen due to other priorities and the abandonment of other tools (Fiddler, HTTP Watch, SUPA, etc.)
 
24. SM50 (ABAP) Logs
Parses SM50 logs into tables and charts for performance and activity analysis. Used only once, but provided essential statistics that helped demystify the issue.
 
25. WER (Windows Error Reporting)
Summarizes WER files.
 
26. WEBI ErrorInfo
Summarizes WebIntelligence.errorinfo files.
 
27. Other Common Features
Interactive search, regular expressions, performance and contextual logs, timers, caching, persistent user settings, save/load capability, and embedded documentation.
 
28. HTTP Client (in development)
HTTP requests to test or verify configurations when it’s not possible or convenient to use a browser, or when the browser is disabled (e.g., on servers). For example, it can send POST requests – similar to a third-party tool like Postman.
Automates RESTful operations.
 
29. Report Structure (in development)
Shows which fields from data sources are used in reports and where.
 
30. Export / Archiving (in development)
Exports or downloads reports to local files in the specified format.

 

 

The motivations and approach behind BiWhy, which I also tried to apply within BiWhy itself.

Software supportability:
Good supportable software rests on following principles:

  • Measure everything
  • Log:
    • Log everything
    • On-the-fly verbosity configuration
    • Centralized configuration (applicable to other topics too)
    • Cut noise:
      • Worthless logs entries
      • Zero error tolerance – a healthy system should be clear of error and exception logs. It is either healthy or has errors; it cannot be both. There shouldn’t be errors that can be ignored. Either fix them or don’t mark them as errors.
      • Easy log filter on step of log generation, as workaround for above two topics
  • Easily available (as simple as possible, ideally one click):
    • Measures
    • Logs
    • Documentations
  • Repeatable problem detection and troubleshooting should be automated or semi-automated
  • Convenient UI to analyze above
  • Non-trivial configurations should be guided and easily troubleshootable at each step

Good supportability means:

  • Problems and performance can be addressed and optimized starting from the lowest level:
    • End users
    • Customer (report)developers
    • System administrators
    • Vendor’s levels of support
    • Vendor’s developers

This will take pressure off higher-tier support layers and save hundreds of hours of support effort per day.
Part of those resources might be redirected to further automation and supportability improvement.

  • Overall, it helps create best-in-class software (functionality richness, performance, robustness, lowest cost of ownership):
    • Early error detection (new and regression) will facilitate new features development and problem correction
    • Performance optimization on all levels –> overall performance gains

Example:

SAP’s success with ABAP systems was to a great extent (imho) due to its open architecture – logs lead to code, the code is easy to debug and measure, and clients can see what is going on and participate in development.

BusinessObjects is addressing supportability in many areas, but it also has a lot of lacunas.
BiWhy was started with idea to fill these gaps.

entry.title: Re: Compensation Statement Acknowledgement Using WalkMe
entry.content:
Hi @mfpabon23 ,

As mentioned at the top of this post, the solution shown is custom configuration and does require additional WalkMe licenses.  It is not part of the standard embedded content.

To build this sample we created a Shout Out with action buttons to prompt the end user to start an automation Smart Walk Thru.  This navigates the user to the statement portlet and then we placed an acknowledgement button on the statement itself which when clicked is stored in the WalkMe reporting tool.

Hope that helps.

Christian

entry.title: SAP Workzone Local Entry Point Theme Manager not working properly
entry.content:
In our multi-tenant app we have set up theming on the subscriber.

All was working fine. The Admin user was able to publish and configure a custom theme to the subsriber Theme Manager, set it as default, and then when a user logged on to the LEP site they got the custom branding.

Now however when we publish the custom theme and try and set  "Enable User Selection" and "Set As Default" in the Theme Manager it looks like it saves but it doesnt.

In the Developer Tools -> Network tab we can see the 

  sap.cf.plugins.ThemeDesign.Component.saveChanges

calls POST https://<<subscriber>>mtx-approuter.cfapps.ap10.hana.ondemand.com/cp.portal/cep/content/v1

 
{
  "query": "\n                    mutation configureTheme($site_id: String!, $settings: ConfigurationSettingsInput!) {\n                        configureTheme(id: $site_id, settings: $settings)\n                    }\n                ",
  "variables": {
    "site_id": "default",
    "settings": {
      "value": {
        "/themeSettings": {
          "defaultTheme": "MegaCorpTheme",
          "availableThemes": [
            "sap_fiori_3",
            "sap_fiori_3_dark",
            "sap_horizon",
            "sap_horizon_dark",
            "sap_horizon_hcb",
            "sap_horizon_hcw",
            "MegaCorpTheme",
            "sap_horizon_set",
            "sap_fiori_3_set"
          ]
        }
      },
      "schemaVersion": "3.2.0"
    }
  }
}
 
it returns
 
{
    "errors": [
        {
            "message": "Request failed with status code 401",
            "path": [
                "configureTheme"
            ],
            "extensions": {
                "statusCode": "INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR"
            }
        }
    ],
    "data": {
        "configureTheme": null
    }
}

The message suggests the user doesnt have access but it does 

 But the admin user definitely has the theming and workzone admin roles assigned

  "role-collections": [
    {
      "name": "Our App Admin LEP Role",
      "description": "Grant Administrative access to LEP",
      "role-template-references": [
..
        "$XSSERVICENAME(ourapp-mtx-workzone).Theme_Admin",
        "$XSSERVICENAME(ourapp-mtx-workzone).Super_Admin",
        "$XSSERVICENAME(ourapp-mtx-workzone).External_User",
        "$XSSERVICENAME(ourapp-theming).Editor",
        "$XSSERVICENAME(ourapp-theming).Publisher",
        "$XSSERVICENAME(ourapp-theming).Viewer",
      ]
    }

entry.title: Re: Facing issues during Depreciation posting in SAP Cloud
entry.content:
Hi R_Pooja,

G-series journal entries (like G000003452) are typically posted in the General Ledger and integrated with Asset Accounting. These entries are stored in standard SAP tables (BKPF, BSEG) and represent system-generated depreciation postings that maintain the link between FI and AA modules.  

And refer to note 3462751 - Error message FAA_MD122 - 'Please change account assignment objects in new time intervals' appears when changing the cost center - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - SAP for Me to better understand error msg.

Did you try to use job template Recalculate Depreciation in app Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs to maitain related value in field ledger and depreciation area 01 and 34?

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better.

Br.Bob

entry.title: Why does SY-FDPOS return 0 when using CO even if the condition is TRUE?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I’m experimenting with ABAP string operations and observed something that I don’t fully understand. Consider the following code:

DATA : lv_ipt1(20) TYPE c VALUE 'System Application',
       lv_ipt2(20) TYPE c VALUE 'System Application'.

IF lv_ipt1 CO lv_ipt2.
  WRITE : 'TRUE', SY-FDPOS.
ELSE.
  WRITE: 'FALSE', SY-FDPOS.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Step-by-step to troubleshooting an authorization issue
entry.content:
The other day, when I logged on to the system and attempted to edit the page layout using “Adapt UI”, I suddenly noticed that the “Adapt UI” option was missing from the user menu.

 

Initially, I suspected this might be related to the new launchpad UI. So I went to “Activate Features” in CBC, turn off the setting /UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE.

 

After refreshing the page, I still couldn't find the "Adapt UI" option under the old UI interface.

 

I remembered that I previously had access to this option in the same system, and I hadn't removed any authorization for my user account. So why had it disappeared?

To investigate the root cause, I needed to verify whether I still had authorization to use "Adapt UI".

I opened the help portal and searched for "Adapt UI" to determine its associated business catalog.

 

Upon clicking the relevant link, I discovered that the business catalog was SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLX_CUS_PC. Meanwhile, I also noticed the IAM app F5933_LRST_TRAN, which reminded me that IAM Apps have now become the smallest authorization unit, rather than business catalogs.

 

At that moment, I realized that the IAM App might have been deactivated. To confirm this, I first needed to identify the business role that contained this IAM App. In the Display IAM Apps, I found that the IAM App F5933_LRST_TRAN was assigned to the Administrator role (BR_ADMINISTRATOR), which I have.

 

To double-check, I went to the Business Catalog and confirmed that the related business catalog was also used in the BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role.

 

I then opened the Maintain Business Roles app, opened BR_ADMINISTRATOR, and under the IAM Apps tab, it confirmed my suspicion - the IAM App F5933_LRST_TRAN was indeed deactivated.

 

I proceeded to edit the business role and reactivated it as follows:

 

After reloading the page and returning to the sales order application, I could finally see the "Adapt UI" option in my user menu!

 

 

Lesson Learnt:

  • IAM App is now the smallest unit for controlling user authorization, not Business Catalog.
  • Some IAM Apps are deactivated by default. Therefore, if you encounter missing authorization issues, always check whether the related IAM App is active.

entry.title: SAP Tax and Revenue Management - What is new for the S/4HANA 2025 (initial) release
entry.content:
Dear readers,

With the S/4HANA 2025 (initial shipment) OnPrem/Private Cloud release, SAP has delivered several new capabilities in its Tax and Revenue Management solution. In this blog, I provide an overview of these developments and what they mean for TRM users:

Enterprise Search Models for Form Bundles and Contact Objects

You can now use Enterprise Search to quickly locate form bundles and contract objects for any business partner and contract account category combination directly from the SAP Fiori launchpad, using predefined search criteria. The results are presented as a worklist that summarizes the relevant form bundles and contract objects and provides actionable items for drilling down into detailed information.

For more information, see:

Help Document: Enterprise Search for Form Bundles Available

Help Document: Enterprise Search for Public Sector Contract Objects Available

Enterprise Search 

 

Expansion of transparent table form framework

 
We are introducing enhanced functionality for managing TTF scenarios, allowing you to easily add, update, and rename form fields. In addition, you can now manually select the package used to create database tables for ISR Form Scenarios, giving you greater control over your setup

For more information, see: Help Document: Enhancements to TTF Framework 

 

Situation Handling for Form Processing mass program 

Use the situation-handling framework to react during the mass activity for form processing (SAP transaction FMCAPFPF) and to monitor form-bundle mass runs with real-time alerts, enabling earlier detection and intervention.

For more information, see: Help Document: Handling Situations

 

Joule Conversational search for Application Help

 
You can now ask questions in natural language in Joule copilot and have Joule answers based on the available documentation in SAP Help Portal for use in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
 
For more information, see: Help Document: Joule Conversational Search
 
Stay tuned for more insights in my next post! Until then, thanks for reading, and feel free to share your thoughts or questions in the comments. 

Diego Gaudenzi, Tax and Revenue Management Product Manager

entry.title: Assign multiple company codes to one posting period variant
entry.content:
We would like to open and close posting periods for multiple company codes at once. We checked on the SAP Note 3598811 - New feature in CE2502 'Assign one posting period variant to multiple company codes' - S/4 HANA Cloud Pubic Edition, however it's not clear how should we proceed in our scenario. 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Assign multiple company codes to one posting period v...
entry.content:
As outlined in KBA 3598811, it is indeed possible to create, maintain, and delete posting period variants within SSCUI 101018 Define Variants for Open Posting Periods configuration.

When you create a new Posting Period Variant, system will issue an Infor message to inform you about the existing naming restriction between Company Code and Posting Period Variant. Specifically, when a Company Code is created, the system automatically generates a Posting Period Variant with the same name. For instance, if you define a custom Posting Period Variant 5000 and later create a Company Code 5000, the system will display an error indicating that the Posting Period Variant 5000 already exists, and this name cannot be used for the new Company Code.

To address your requirement, you have two options:

  1. You can create a new Posting Period Variant, ensuring that you do not create a Company Code with the same name in the future.
  2. Alternatively, you can reuse an existing Posting Period Variant.

Once you have selected a Posting Period Variant, you can assign it to multiple Company Codes that you wish to manage collectively. This can be done in SSCUI 105409 Assign Fiscal Year Variants to Ledgers and Company Codes configuration.

For example, if your current setup assigns each Company Code (e.g., 1010, 1020, 1030, etc.) to its own Posting Period Variant with the same name, you may decide to use Posting Period Variant 1010 to manage all Company Codes. In this case, you would assign the chosen variant to the remaining Company Codes, replacing their default Posting Period Variants with the same name.
